links.quantification: Community ownership → 1000 sensors deployed by residents → 100m resolution vs. 10km regulatory monitors → intra-city inequality exposed (3x variation)
Traffic hotspot identification → 40 high-NO2 intersections mapped → targeted signal timing changes → 15% localized pollution reduction for ₹5L investment
Fence-line monitoring → 18 factories exceeding limits identified → community complaints validated → ₹50 Cr penalties issued
Waste fire real-time alerts → 200 burning events detected/year → community firefighting response time 15 min vs. 4 hours → 60% PM2.5 spike reduction
Data quality concerns: Low-cost sensors ±30% accuracy → regulatory acceptance resisted → calibration protocols needed → 2-year validation period
Local data → community action → pollution improves → sensor credibility grows → more neighbourhoods demand sensors (reinforcing adoption)
Requires digital literacy: Community sensing only effective with 50% smartphone penetration + data visualization apps → capacity building prerequisite
Via micro-planning: Hotspot data → street redesigns → 25 car-free zones created → pedestrian PM2.5 exposure -40%
Via compliance: Fence-line pressure → industrial controls installed → local health improves → community monitoring trust in institutions grows
Via enforcement: Fire detection data → municipal waste collection improves → ₹100 Cr infrastructure upgrades → systemic fire prevention
